text:
Suppose the following dataframe, filtered by horses who model predicted odds was between `8 <> 8.02`. `winOdd` is the model projected odds for the horse.

From the universe of *1127* horses, *128* horses finished in 1st (~10.5%).

In the second example filtered by horses who model predicted odds was between `4 <> 4.02`

From the universe of *889* horses, *213* horses finished in 1st (~24%).

It's a valid approach to confirm that the model has an edge?

text: On one hand, you may have a calibration issue imho: your model says it should have ~12.5% of winning probability and you get 22% ?  It seems to scale correctly from this example (double the odds, half the probability), but the real question is not whether the model has an edge on its own, but whether it has an edge w.r.t. what other models do. When do odds of your model and odds of betfair disagree, what happens, for example?

text: If your model predicts odd X you expect the horse to win 1/X. In your first case, the 95% CI is 9.6% to 13.3%, which includes the 10.5% you have. Great. This means your model is not that bad at computing odds. This is the calibration and prediction aspect.

elements.text: If your model predicts odd X you expect the horse to win 1/X. In your first case, the 95% CI is 9.6% to 13.3%, which includes the 10.5% you have. Great. This means your model is not that bad at computing odds. This is the calibration and prediction aspect.

text: Now the question is: edge against which baseline? Because an edge means you are better at predicting something, but you need a baseline to compute against. You need to identify horses in which the wisdom of the crowd is odd X but you spit out odd Y, and you are right, to say you have an edge

text:
I think you're overthinking it. Just backtest it over 10,000 runners for example - if modelWinOdd > bsp then back at bsp price, if modelWinOdd < bsp then lay at bsp price. Make sure you're calculating your P&L correctly!

1. Use simple staking proportional to price.
2. Try adding a threshold where you only back / lay if model disagrees with market > certain impl %
3. Stake relative to your estimated edge, so proportional to price but also abs(modelImpl - marketImpl)

You need to do this for each individual runner - don't bucket runners into a "price range". Treat each individual runner as its own bet. Only then will you properly be benchmarking against bsp.

For your model to stand a chance as a working strategy then the above should really work.

2. Try adding a threshold where you only back / lay if model disagrees with market > certain impl %
3. Stake relative to your estimated edge, so proportional to price but also abs(modelImpl - marketImpl)

You need to do this for each individual runner - don't bucket runners into a "price range". Treat each individual runner as its own bet. Only then will you properly be benchmarking against bsp.

For your model to stand a chance as a working strategy then the above should really work.

text:
When is your model price calculated? Is it calculable at any time, or only at the off, or does it use BSP as an input as well?

If it's calculable at any time then you could also try backtesting betting earlier in the day. Prices tend to less efficient then, but there is less volume available. But to do that you'll need to use tick data.

text:
Personally, to keep it simple I'll just use bsp for backtesting sometimes. You can achieve something close to bsp if you think about execution strategy.

vwap calculated a few seconds before the off is going to be very close to bsp. But that is equally impossible to know since you don't know when it's going to go off!

vwap across the whole history of pre-race is not going to be close to bsp.

elements.text:

vwap calculated a few seconds before the off is going to be very close to bsp. But that is equally impossible to know since you don't know when it's going to go off!

vwap across the whole history of pre-race is not going to be close to bsp.

text: I would try backtesting earlier in the day, say 1 hour before race start, or at around 9am, for example. With those bets that get placed (assume same strategy of model vs market price) do they beat bsp? i.e. can you close at bsp for a better price consistently?

elements.text: I would try backtesting earlier in the day, say 1 hour before race start, or at around 9am, for example. With those bets that get placed (assume same strategy of model vs market price) do they beat bsp? i.e. can you close at bsp for a better price consistently?

text:
If you're not beating bsp by betting earlier, then it means you're better off betting at bsp, and generally that means you don't have an edge. (Betting at bsp just means you're losing less).

Sorry, if I'm just confusing you!
